School of Environmental Science and Engineering State Key Lab of Metal Matrix Composites Shanghai Jiao Tong University 800 Dongchuan Road Shanghai 200240 China Graphical abstract Chitin and microalgae, naturally occurring nitrogen-rich marine resources, have vast applications in chemical production and material synthesis. Being undervalued and underutilized for a long time, marine biomass biorefinery has attracted considerable attention to realize its economic value in the last few years to meet the sustainable development requirements. This review first analyzes the chemical constituent of chitin and microalgae to understand their basic chemical properties. Next, various transformation pathways to value-added nitrogenous chemicals are summarized, and the biologically fixed nitrogen in marine biomass can be fully utilized with the reduced amount of energy-intensive synthetic NH3. Additionally, the biomass can also be used as precursors to synthesize functional N- doped carbon materials, which are potential candidates in catalysts, energy storage, and biomedical field. This review can provide insights into the fundamental understanding on the intrinsic nature and appropriate transformation options for N-rich marine biomass as renewable replacement of non-sustainable petroleum resources, and also disclose the nitrogen utilization from biomass for wider and more sustainable applications to enrich the chemicals production process. Keywords Marine biomass Chitin Microalgae Utilization 1 Introduction Petroleum resources have been the primary energy and materials sources for modern society. However, overdependence on fossil fuels will expose pollution to our environment, especially air pollution. The gaseous pollutants are highly related to a well-known world problem: greenhouse gases, posing many threats to human health and balance of environment and ecology [1]. Consequently, it is necessary to find alternatives for fossil fuels. Biomass, one of the most critical carbon resources in nature, is a good alternative, and many researchers have studied how to transform biomass into various high-value chemicals, fuels and functional materials [2,3]. The development history of biofuels experienced three distinct generations [4]. During the first generation, food based feedstock, such as sugarcane and corn [5], are used for bioethanol production to reduce people’s demand for fossil oils. However, since the first generation occupies too much land and food source, the second generation occurred, using non-edible biomass residues based on lignocellulose biomass, for instance, straws [6], rice husk [7], and bagasse [8]. Taking lignocellulose for an example, researchers have succeeded in converting lignocellulose into renewable biobased fuels and chemicals such as bioethanol [9], 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) [10], levulinic acid (LA) [11]. Among them, both 5-HMF and LA are platform chemicals available from carbohydrates and have been included in the list of “top value added chemicals from biomass” in 2004 [12]. Moreover, 2,5-furanedicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a green alternative to petroleum-based chemical terephthalic acid for the production of various polymers, could be generated from 5-HMF [13]. While cheap and clean, it is difficulty in the biomass refinery and upgrading related to the lignocellulose utilization [14]. Besides, lignocellulosic feedstock, usually terrestrial plants, need enough land to grow. To tackle these problems, microalgae become the third generation biomass resources due to its fast growth rate and minimal environmental impacts [4,15]. Till now, numerous investigators have studied to transform microalgae into carbon-neutral fuels like bioethanol [16] and biomethane [17]. Fig. 1 sums up the comparisons between these three generation biomass. Like microalgae, chitin, the second largest natural polysaccharide biopolymer with the estimated production of 1010-1011 T per year, is abundant in aquatic ecosystems [22,23]. Abundant in nature, chitin is an insoluble copolymer consisting of linear chains of β(1→4)-linked 2-acetamido-2-deoxy-d-glucan (Fig. 2 ) [24], and the primary source is crustacean wastes, especially shrimps and craps. The output of shell waste from crustacean is about 1.44 million metric tons of dry weight every year, and the inherent nitrogen in chitin is about 7 wt% [25–27]. Chitosan is the deacetylated form of chitin with deacetylation degree between 60 % and 80 %, playing an essential part in biomedical application (Fig. 2) [28]. The structure of chitin is similar to that of cellulose, but chitin has an acetamide group instead of a hydroxy at C2. Microalgae mainly comprise lipids, carbohydrates and proteins [29]. Nitrogen fixed in microalgae is mainly in the form of protein, and as shown in Table 1 , protein occupies a very important position in microalgae with high nitrogen content. Since many researchers have studied to produce biofuels from lipids, it will be more interesting and meaningful to convert microalgae into versatile N-containing chemicals (NCCs) [30,31]. Since the cell wall of microalgae species is rigid, suitable extraction methods for protein derived from microalgae are necessary, including microwave irradiation, ultrasonic extraction, enzymatic treatment and so on [32]. While much research effect have been devoted to the transformation of typical biomass composed of carbon(C), hydrogen(H), and oxygen(O) elements, very few explorations have studied the utilization of nitrogen(N) containing marine biomass such as microalgae and chitin. Nevertheless, NCCs have widespread applications in materials, fine chemicals and biomedical applications, and effective conversion chitin and microalgae to value added NCCs is a potential strategy to achieve marine biomass valorization [33]. However, industrial production of NCCs require much energy- intensive synthetic ammonia (NH3) or its derivatives. The Haber-Bosch process for the production of NH3 needs to break the strong NN triple bond in nitrogen gas as well as consume around 50 % H2 supply which mainly from fossil fuel reforming [34]. Considering the high cost and pollution of NH3 synthesis, manufacturing NCCs from nitrogen-containing biomass feedstock such as chitin and microalgae will be more sustainable and meaningful. This review focuses on the recent reports on marine biomass utilization for the production of NCCs, which are traditionally produced by introducing NH3 via the Haber-Bosch process. It describes the valorization of marine biomass: various methods of producing NCCs and the prospect of being a source of functional materials. 2 Utilization of chitin 2.1 Conversion into functional carbon materials Recently, carbon-based materials have attracted numerous interest because of widespread applications in catalysts [38], bioimaging [39], and energy storage [40]. To improve chemical properties of these materials, introducing heteroatoms such as nitrogen holds great promise. However, traditional nitrogen sources are usually from acetonitrile [41], aniline [42], and pyridine [43]. Consequently, chitin is an alternative to these petroleum feedstock. 2.1.1 Direct carbonization Direct carbonization refers to the materials synthesized in an inert atmosphere under high temperature without hydrothermal treatment. Du et al. [44] first used NaOH/urea solution to increase the solubility of chitin under low temperature without adverse effects on chitin structure. Based on this solvents system, Duan and co-workers [45] synthesized N-doped carbon nanofibrous microspheres with a unique framework structure from chitin. Wang et al. [46] successfully prepared honeycomb-like N-doped carbon/graphene materials based on chitin and graphene. Chitin and graphene oxide were mixed in NaOH/urea solution, repeated freezing/thawing cycles, and coagulated in ethanol. The resulting solid was carbonized at 800 °C for 2 h, denoted as N-DC/G. Specifically, N-DC/G showed outstanding electrochemical activity for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). In another report, Chen et al. [47] fabricated hierarchically porous N-doped carbon materials (NCS) from chitin (Fig. 3 ). Chitin first dissolved in NaOH/urea solution, went through emulsion and obtained chitin microsphere. Finally, the chitin microsphere was further carbonized at 800 °C. The incorporation of nitrogen not only improved the absorbance of potassium but enhanced electronic conductivity of NCS. Lu et al. [48] synthesized N-doped carbon nanofiber aerogels from chitin with ∼5.3 at.% nitrogen content after KOH activation. The as-prepared N-doped materials exhibited outstanding Na+ storage and stable cycling performance of 238 mA h g−1 after 7000 cycles. In a study by Wu et al. [49], the synthesized materials called N-doped carbon (C-Chitin)/graphitic C3N4 (g-C3N4) showed outstanding properties in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Dicyandiamide was heated to prepare g-C3N4, which mixed with chitin in NaOH/urea aqueous. Then the suspension went through freezing/thawing cycles and coagulation, and the gels were carbonized at 800 °C for 2 h. The novel and simple synthesis was able to produce large scale of chitin-based materials with low cost. Ma et al. [50] developed a novel cathode CCN/SeS2 with SeS2 tightly confined in chitin-derived carbon nanosheets (CCN). SeS2 was incorporated in CCN by a melting method (CCN/SeS2), displaying superior stability with enhanced Na+ mobility and reaction resistances reduction. Wang et al. [51] incorporated Mo2C into a chitin/graphene oxide aerogel, and it exhibited good cycling stability and excellent performance in hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalytic activity. Li et al. [52] investigated three activators (H3PO4, KOH, and KHCO3) to prepare oxygen electrodes for Li-O2 batteries with chitin as the precursor. Chitin suspended in different solutions followed by pretreatment, carbonization and removal of activators. According to the different activation processes, It found that CA (activated by H3PO4) exhibited a specific capacity of 16,600 mA h g−1 at 0.02 mA cm-2 and high stability after 210 cycles without capacity loss. Nevertheless, there are still some shortcomings of N-doped carbon materials, such as suffering low graphitization and a low level of nitrogen-doping, which are highly related to active sites and catalytic properties [49]. It is essential to improve the performance of these materials for broader and more practical applications. Also, it is necessary to choose suitable activators and carbonization temperature for the synthetic process. 2.1.2 Hydrothermal carbonization Di et al. [53] synthesized materials from chitin hydrothermally. First, N/S dual-doped chitin-derived carbon materials (SCCh) were prepared by carbonizing S and chitin directly. Next, the mixture of SCCh and graphene solution was hydrothermally treated at 180 °C for 10 h followed by a freeze-drying process, denoted as rGO-SCCh. It was noteworthy that the optimized rGO-SCCh composite counter electrode in dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) achieved a photovoltaic performance with a power conversion efficiency of 6.36 %. In another experiment by Zheng et al. [54], shrimp shells were used to prepare nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon materials. Chitin was soaked in HCl solution to generate a porous structure. Afterward, the treated solids mixed with a phosphoric acid solution, which were subsequently heated at 160 ℃ (Scheme 1 ). Finally, the as-prepared materials were carbonized at 800–1000 ℃ for 2 h. The authors demonstrated that the treatment of H3PO4 generated more defects as well as larger surface area. Nguyen et al. [55] fabricated chiral N-doped carbon-sheath nanofibers via physical exfoliation and hydrothermal carbonization at 190 ℃, exhibiting high surface area (>300 m2 g−1) and preference to absorb d-lactic acid rather than l-lactic acid. It provided novel enantioselective nanomaterials in a greener, low-cost, and sustainable way. Incorporating heteroatoms into the materials can be realized in a hydrothermal process. It is energy-saving since the fabrication process is in mild conditions. 2.1.3 Template carbonization The control on the morphology and pore structure can be realized by template carbonization. Liang [56] produced a N-doped mesoporous carbon from chitosan with tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) as a template and nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2) as a catalyst. Zhang et al. [57] synthesized B/N co-doped carbon with chitin and boric acid as a precursor and template, respectively (Fig. 4 ). Chitin in a boric acid solution went through evaporation followed by drying at 100 ℃ for 12 h. Carbonization temperature in N2 was vital in the surface area with around 1200 and 1400 m2 g−1 at 800 ℃ and 600 ℃, while 225 m2 g−1 at 400 ℃. It turned out that boron nitride (BN) bonds, mainly determining the catalytic activity, were formed in the synthetic materials and strengthened by a higher carbonization temperature. Template carbonization modulated the structure to fabricate porous carbon materials. Specifically, a suitable template is essential in the synthetic process, ensuring that it will do no harm to the structure and be useful to enhance the surface area and performance. 2.1.4 Impregnation-carbonization To improve electrocatalytic performance, Chen et al. [58] synthesized a porous carbon material from chitin loaded with Co and S. They impregnated CoCl2 and ZnCl2 with chitin, and then the mixture went direct carbonization in N2 at 1000 ℃ for 2 h (denoted as Co-N-C). To further increase the functionality of Co-N-C, the authors tried to add S via a hydrothermal treatment (Fig. 5 ). Importantly, sulfurization increased the surface area and generated defects. In another study by Zhai et al. [59], non-noble metal Ni as well as Co, was loaded on chitin to synthesize a bimetal catalyst. Chitin was carbonized at an optimized temperature (600 ℃) to prepare porous structure N-doped carbon support (NC-600). Then the solution Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was impregnated on chitin and reduced under H2. The synergetic effect of CoNi alloy particles and the existence of nitrogen enhanced the catalytic ability and selectivity to convert vanillin to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol. Impregnating non-precious metal on chitin-derived materials is able to generate novel functional materials and lower the cost instead of using precious metals such as Pt and Pd. Also, the synergetic effect of metal and nitrogen largely increase its catalytic performance. 2.2 Conversion into nitrogen-containing chemicals N-acetyl-d-glucosamine (GlcNAc), a monomer of chitin, has an acetamide group at C2 which enables chitin to be the precursor of various NCCs. In contrast to the Haber-Bosch process, inherent nitrogen will relieve pollution pressure. Fig. 6 shows various NCCs produced from chitin, chitosan and their monomers. 2.2.1 Amine and amide sugars Chitin and chitosan have broad applications in biomedical science [60], food [61] and cosmetics [62], whereas the limited solubility discourages them from displaying their value fully. As a result, hydrolyzing chitin or chitosan into monomers (GlcNAc, GlcNH2), or their oligomers which have great potential in medical treatment, precursors for chemical synthesis and additives in cosmetic fields, may maximize their profit. Overall, there are two traditional methods to hydrolyze chitin or chitosan: enzymatic hydrolysis and acid hydrolysis. MOJARRAD et al. [63] degraded chitin into glucosamine hydrochloride by HCl, and the yield was up to 97 % at 100 ℃ for 4 h. Santos-Moriano et al. [64] extracted chitosanolytic activity from Bacillus thuringiensis to synthesize a mixture of deacetylated oligosaccharides from chitosan (Fig. 7 ). The obtained soluble solution of oligosaccharides from 10 g/L chitosan included (GlcN)2 (1.6 g/L), (GlcN)3 (1.7 g/L), (GlcN)4 (5 g/L), and (GlcN)5 (1.4 g/L). Additionally, Chen et al. [65] first treated chitin in a bacterial fermentative process, which was called CBF, and confirmed that the pretreatment promoted enzymatic hydrolysis of chitin into GlcNAc which decreasd chitin crystallinity and improved the chitinase catalytic activity with almost 100 % conversion of CBF into GlcNAc within 6 h. Recently, a combination of chemical pretreatment and enzyme hydrolysis was proved to largely enhance GlcNH2 production [66]. Apart from the traditional methods mentioned above, imidazolium-based ionic liquids contributed to 60 % reducing sugars at 100 ℃ for 7 h in the presence of 6.0 wt% HCl [67]. In another report, pretreating chitin with room temperature ionic liquids ([C2mim][OAc]) improved the efficiency of enzymatic degradation to its monomer [68]. Besides, Chen et al. [69] produced more than 90 % reducing sugars from chitosan under microwave irradiation in sulfonic acid-functionalized ionic liquids (SFILs). Additionally, microwave-assisted acid hydrolysis could improve the yield of GlcN.HCl from chitin up to 57 % in 12 min and ultrasonication promoted chitin dissolution in the acid solution below 40 ℃ [70]. Apart from these, solid acid treatment has been used to depolymerize chitosan to GlcNH2, and the catalyst based on glucose in a hydrothermal treatment led to 98.1 % yield of GlcNH2 [71]. Moreover, in recent years, mechanochemical degradation of chitin was developed. Impregnating chitin with H2SO4 followed by ball milling led to 100 % soluble compounds [72]. Subsequently, the treated chitin was hydrolyzed to GlcNAc with a yield of 53 %. When the ball-milled compounds dissolved in methanol, it led to 70 % 1-O-methyl-N-acetylglucosamine yield. In the reaction, chitin crystallinity was decreased since ball-milling increased chitin accessibility. Next, the synergetic effect of mechanical force and H2SO4 improved the cleavage of glycosidic bonds and preserved acetamide groups (Scheme 2 ). Zhang and Yan [73] proposed a co-solvent system to promote hydrolysis and deacetylation of chitin. First, the ball-mill treatment decreased the crystallinity of chitin. Then the treated chitin was converted into GlcNH2 with sulfuric acid as catalysts, and the yield of GlcNH2 reached 80 % at 175 ℃ for 1 h. Margoutidis et al. [74] processed chitin by the ball-mill treatment with the addition of kaolinite. Ball milling decreased the crystallinity of chitin, and kaolinite enhanced the solubility of treated chitin up to 75.8 % in 6 h, including 5.1 wt% GlcNAc and 3.9 wt% (GlcNAc)2. Recently, Yan et al. designed acidified lithium halide molten salt hydrate (AMSH) systems composing of 60 wt% LiBr and 40 mM HCl for the production of GlcNAc from chitin, which eventually led to 71.5 % GlcNAc at 120 ℃ in 0.5 h [75]. The characterization of 13C Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and Attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) confirmed that Li+ changed the hydrogen-bonding network of chitin, which resulted in chitin dissolution and hydrolysis. Pierson et al. [76] studied the liquefaction of chitin in ethylene glycol (EG) using sulfuric acid as catalysts, and more than 75 % of chitin was degraded to liquid products at 165 ℃ within 90 min. The main products were hydroxyethyl-2-amino-2-deoxyhexopyranoside (HADP) and hydroxyethyl-2-acetamido-2-deoxyhexopyranoside (HAADP) with a total yield of 30 %. HAADP formed quickly at the initial stage, and then deacetylated to HADP (Fig. 8 ). According to the kinetic study, acid improved the cleavage of the glycosidic band and generated an oxonium intermediate with an enhancement of the electrophilicity on C1. Subsequently, EG promoted a nucleophilic attack to form HAADP followed by hydrolysis to form HADP. Afterward, the same group chose formic acid as a liquefaction solvent to compensate for the disadvantages in the EG system [77]. Compared to sulfuric acid, formic acid was lower in acidity with fewer side reactions, and 100 % liquefaction was obtained at mild conditions. Although enzymatic hydrolysis and acid hydrolysis effectively convert chitin into various monomers and oligomers, the former is time-consuming as well as sensitive to the reaction conditions, and the latter is detrimental to the environment. Other methods, like microwave heating or ultrasonication, are conducive to shortening the time or dissolving chitin. Furthermore, the mechanical pretreatment can destroy hydrogen bonding among polymers. It is worth understanding and finding more reasonable approaches to enrich the hydrolysis process, and catalysts with good recyclability should be developed to decrease the cost. 2.2.2 Amine and amide polyols Polyols such as sorbitol from glucose even cellulose hydrogenation have great potential in the fields of food and pharmaceutics [78]. However, there are few studies focus on N-containing polyols production which can be used to synthesize high-valued NCCs. Recently, some researchers converted GlcNAc over noble metal catalysts into polyols via hydrogenation [79]. The authors selected four metal catalysts: Ru/C, Rh/C, Pd/C, and Pt/C. Among them, Ru/C performed best with 71.9 % C6 polyols, 6.1 % C4 polyols, and 8.7 % N-acetylmonoethanolamine (NMEA) at 180 ℃ under 40 bar H2 for 1 h. GlcNAc was almost completely hydrogenated into 2-acetamido-2-deoxysorbitol (ADS) at 80 ℃. When the temperature was above 180 ℃, the amount of methane increased with more side reactions. According to different products, the authors proposed four reaction pathways (Fig. 9 ). Kobayashi et al. [80] produced 2-acetamido-2-deoxysorbitol (ADS) from chitin in two steps of hydrolysis and hydrogenation after mechanocatalytic conversion (Scheme 3 ). At first, the authors converted chitin in a mechanical process with the H2SO4 addition to GlcNAc and oligomers with a total yield of 83 % (19 % GlcNAc and 64 % oligomer, Step 1) which could be for the following production of ADS without purification. On the one hand, the mixtures could be transformed into ADS with a yield of 25 % by the hydrolytic hydrogenation at 180 ℃ in one step (Step 2a). On the other hand, the mixtures could be further hydrolyzed to 61 % GlcNAc at 175 ℃(Step 2b), and then, with NaHCO3 adjusting pH around 3–4, the yield of ADS was increased to 52 % using Ru/TiO2 as the catalyst at 120 ℃ (Step 3b), comparing to 37 % yield of ADS without base addition (Step 3a). Furthermore, the same group investigated to convert ADS into 2-acetamide-2-deoxyisosorbide (ADI) which was a potential precursor to produce N-containing polymers [81]. They demonstrated that the dehydration condensation process catalyzed by CH3SO3H obtained 33 % yield of ADI under the optimized conditions, and it unlocked the potential of other NCCs production in organic reactions from ADI which could dissolve in various organic solvents unlike ADS. Since different reaction routes processed under different temperature, a suitable reaction condition is important for the hydrogenation of chitin monomers. Additionally, choosing an efficient catalyst can improve the purity of the products and simplify the following procedures. 2.2.3 Amino acids Amino acids occupy an important position in people’s lives with wide applications in food, medical treatment and dietary supplement. Generally, industrial production of amino acids largely depends on fermentation and chemical synthesis. However, fermentation need much equipment investment and is time-consuming; traditional chemical process such as the Strecker reaction brings environmental threat since nonrenewable cyanides are used [82]. Recently, lignocellulosic biomass-derived α-hydroxyl acids were transformed into amino acids by Yan et al. in high yields with NH3 as nitrogen source [83]. However, chitin and its derivatives with inherent nitrogen could avoid the use of external nitrogen in a more environment-friendly way. Glucosaminic acid (GlcNA), an important amino acid, has been considered as a potential condiment, a precursor which can be used in pharmaceutical synthesis as well as biocompatible ligand chelated with metals which can be practiced in medical science [84]. Ohmi et al. obtained 93 % yield of GlcNA from chitosan monomer catalyzed by supported Au nanoparticles with oxygen as oxidant at 40 ℃ for 3 h [85]. The study confirmed that the oxidation performance of the catalyst was positively correlated with the support basicity. While Au supported on hydrotalcite (HT) or MgO effectively promoted oxidation reaction, Au/MgO performed better in recycling experiments since Au interacted strongly with Au nanoparticles with growth inhibition of Au particle. It really achieved a high yield of GlcNA, however, utilizing cheaper feedstock like chitosan will be more promising. Yan et al. further GlcNA from chitosan via tandem hydrolysis and oxidation [84]. Amberlyst-15 promoted the chitosan hydrolysis to GlcNH2, which was further converted to GlcNA with Au/MgO as the catalyst at oxygen atmosphere. To improve GlcNA yield, the undesired products generated in the hydrolysis step was removed by activated carbon which was favorable for the subsequent oxidation, finally resulting in 36 % yield of GlcNA. Besides GlcNA, Fukuoka et al. [86] employed Ru/C as the catalyst to convert GlcNAc into acetylglycine (AcGly) in two steps (Scheme 4 ). Firstly, GlcNAc was converted to NMEA via a retro-aldol reaction and a subsequent hydrogenation catalyzed by Ru/C in NaHCO3 aqueous medium. To reduce the formation of ADS, the reactor was not pressured with H2 until the reactor achieved the desired temperature which finally obtained 29 % (based on N) yield of NMEA. Next, Ru/C was employed as the catalyst for NMEA oxidation to AcGly in an NaHCO3 aqueous solution under O2 pressure. The further characterization of Ru/C displayed that small hydrous RuO2 clusters with hydroxo, aqua, μ-hydroxo, and μ-oxo ligands worked as the catalytic active species for NMEA oxidation. This work provides a different method for amino acids production as well as insights for catalytic system design to inhibit other side reactions. In general, synthesizing amino acids from chitin and its derivatives has a promising future, and employing chitin or chitosan, which are easily available, as the feedstock may be more attractive. The key is to find a suitable catalytic system which can not only break the glycosidic bonds, but also improve the product selectivity and yield. 2.2.4 N-containing furan derivatives Like 5-HMF from glucose, GlcNAc can be converted to 3-acetamido-5-acetylfuran (3A5AF), and the yield was no more than 2% via a pyrolysis process [87,88]. 3A5AF is a versatile chemical for the production of various chemicals. A pioneer work by Drover et al. [89] converted GlcNAc to 3A5AF in 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride [BMim]Cl under microwave heating with B(OH)3 as an additive. Boric acid increased the yield of 3A5AF up to 60 %, and ionic liquids damaged hydrogen bonds between GlcNAc. A possible pathway was proposed in path 1(Scheme 5 ). First, acidic proton on imidazolium ring promoted the generation of open-chain aldose form of GlcNAc, which subsequently underwent ring closure to form a 5-membered heterocycle. Next, the heterocycle was converted to 3A5AF via dehydration and keto-enol tautomerization process. In another study, the yield reached 62 % in dimethylacetamide (DMA) under microwave irradiation with NaCl and B(OH)3 as additives [90]. The author also demonstrated that water inhibited the reaction. Later, Yan’s group synthesized 3A5AF from chitin directly (an overview of reaction conditions being shown in Fig. 10 ). By screening among 6 solvents and 26 additives, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) was the best solvent with B(OH)3 and alkaline chlorides as additives [26]. Under optimal conditions, 7.5 % 3A5AF was obtained with 50 % chitin conversion. NMR spectroscopy and poison tests confirmed the boric acid coordinated with GlcNAc and formed a six-membered ring by interacting with the substrate on C4 and C6. After heating, the β-anomer of GlcNAc appeared, indicating boric acid promoted the ring-opening step and subsequently stimulated the generation of 3A5AF. Since organic solvents were toxic and environmental-unfriendly, the group converted chitin into 3A5AF in ILs [91]. Consequently, the yield of 3A5AF was 6.2 % in [BMim]Cl with B(OH)3 and HCl as additives. Then, different pretreatment methods were tested to damage the robust structure of chitin, and ball mill grinding in dry mode outperformed than other methods with the yield up to 28.5 % [92]. In a recent publication, a novel method was proposed to produce 3A5AF from GlcNAc, which was catalyzed by amino acid ionic liquids (AAILs) [93]. Among a wide range of AAILs, the highest yield of 3A5AF was 43.22 % in DMA with glycine chloride ([Gly]Cl) ionic liquid as a catalyst, and Cl−1 of [Gly]Cl disrupted hydrogen bond of GlcNAc. Fukuoka et al. [94] employed AlCl3·6H2O, a cheap Lewis acid, to obtain 3A5AF from GlcNAc in N,N-dimethylformamide, and finally achieved 30 % yield at 120 ℃ within 30 min which could be isolated with 98 % purity by simple column chromatography. Apart from 3A5AF, 2-acetamido-2,3-dideoxy-d-erythro-hex-2-enofuranose (Chromogen I) and 3-acetamido-5-(1′,2′-dihydroxyethyl) furan (Chromogen III) can also be obtained from GlcNAc conversion in a non-catalytic system [95]. Specifically, the yield was highly related to temperature with 23 % of Chromogen I at 190 ℃ and 23.1 % of Chromogen III at 220 ℃ respectively. As path 2 demonstrated (Scheme 5), the open ring of GlcNAc went through dehydration between H-2 and OH-3, followed by ring closure to form Chromogen Ⅰ. It was easy to eliminate H-2 due to the electron-withdrawing property of the acetyl amide group. When the temperature was over 180 ℃, Chromogen I would dehydrate to Chromogen III, further decomposing with a temperature above 200 ℃ (Scheme 5). First-order kinetic model is suitable for the reaction. The activation for Chromogen I formation (85.7 kJ mol−1) was lower than that for Chromogen III (105 kJ mol−1), confirming that a higher temperature was conducive to Chromogen III. Later, the group used (GlcNAc)2 as the starting materials [96]. Though adopted a similar system as before, the highest yield of Chromogen I and III was only 5.4 % and 8.0 %, attributed to the insufficient hydrolysis of the glycosidic bond. Very recently, the group proposed to synthesize Chromogen I with chitin as a starting material in high-temperature water [97]. About 90 % of soluble materials generated and Chromogen I was in 2.6 % yield under optimized conditions. Another breakthrough was achieved by Zheng et al. [98]. They dehydrated GlcNAc to form Chromogen I of 40 % yield with the help of lanthanide complexes (Fig. 11 ). Lanthanide ion played an essential role in GlcNAc dehydration via the coordination of Chromogen I ligand. By comparison with the traditional approach of synthesizing Chromogen I, this method could easily separate Chromogen I in good yields under mild conditions. 3A5AF and other furan derivatives are significant platform chemicals in industries. The selection of solvents and appropriate additives leads to a high yield of 3A5AF with GlcNAc as the starting materials. To develop their great potential and extensive use in various fields like medicine, the effective production of 3A5AF directly from chitin should be considered by designing a multifunctional catalytic system. In light of the strong hydrogen-bond in chitin, mild pretreatment process is conducive to the following dehydration. 2.2.5 N-containing heterocycles pyrroles and pyrazines Heterocyclic compounds and derivatives are significant chemotherapeutic agents [99]. The heterocyclic products of GlcNAc during a pyrolysis process included pyrazines, pyridines, and pyrrole [87]. Gao et al. produced pyrroles from chitin in one step [100]. With extra ammonia, the pyrrole yield reached 6% at 325 ℃ for 1 min in 1 M NaOH. The authors raised a possible reaction pathway (Fig. 12 ): chitin hydrolysis formed GlcNAc, and then dehydrated to generate furanic chemicals, followed by deamination and oxygen-nitrogen exchange to form a pyrrole ring. Finally, the side chain was broken, and pyrrole generated. Besides pyrrole, deoxyfructosazine (DOF) and fructosazine (FZ) have been investigated since the derivatives can work as flavoring agents in the fields of food and tobacco [101]. In a study by Shu [102], the degradation products of glucosamine were different under various reaction conditions. Specifically, when pH was 4 or 7, the major products were furfurals; and when pH was 8.5, pyrazine and methylpyrazine were the major products. In 2001, Rohovecv et al. [103] reported that DOF could be synthesized from glucosamine hydrochloride in aqueous solution in the presence of phenylboronate or borate. Borate had a high affinity for the GlcNH2 in the open form by interacting with OH-3, OH-4, and NH2-2, and this form constituted a high proportion in borate esters. Then, the dihydropyrazine derivative was generated by condensation of two molecules of compounds. Finally, after a dehydration process followed by isomerization, DOF was synthesized via acidification. In recent years, ILs displayed as solvents and catalysts, encouraging the production of DOF and FZ with GlcNH2 as raw materials (an overview of ILs Fig. 13 ). A total yield of DOF and FZ reached 49 % at 120 ℃ for 3 h in 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide ([BMIM]OH) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [104]. Afterward, the author and co-workers investigated the mechanism with 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate [C2C1Im][OAc] as the catalyst and solvent [105]. Notably, CH3COO−, as the primary catalyst, was hydrogen bonding acceptor and able to form hydrogen bonding between [C2C1Im][OAc] and GlcNH2. CH3COO− strengthened the nucleophilic ability of lone pair electrons on the nitrogen, and imidazolium cations increased the electrophilic capability of aldehyde. Also, CH3COO− improved interconversion of the α-anomer and the β-anomer with increasing concentration of open-chain form of GlcNH2. In another study, the yield of DOF increased to 40.2 % with B(OH)3 as an additive [106]. The formation of the boron complex was confirmed by NMR, electron spray ionization–mass spectroscopy (ESI-MS), and density functional theory (DFT), and boron coordination effects were conducive to ring-opening and the following dehydration reaction. Given that ILs were not suitable for industrial process due to high costs, Wu and co-workers [101] used choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents (ChCl-based DESs) as solvents and catalysts to convert GlcNH2 into DOF and FZ. The yield of DOF was increased from 13.5%–30.1% with amino acids as cocatalysts under optimized conditions. As shown in Scheme 6 , GlcNH2 was first converted to its open ring-form, and then dihydrofructosazine formed via an intermolecular nucleophilic addition. At last, the conversion had two paths: one converts dihydrofructosazine to DOF by dehydration and rearrangement; another converts dihydrofructosazine to FZ through dehydrogenation. During the reaction, arginine interacted with GlcNH2 via hydrogen bond and accelerated ring-open form to promote the following reaction. Pyrazines and its derivatives are essential in the pharmaceutical industry, and the synthesis of DOF or FZ is related to glucosamine self-condensation. ILs can play two roles in the condensation: catalysts and solvents, however, ILs are not appliable in scale up of production of pyrazines. Thus, finding a cost-effective and green catalyst is high on the list, and more chemicals can be further produced from pyrazines for wider applications. 3 Utilization of protein or amino acids 3.1 Conversion into functional materials Carbon-based quantum dots have huge potential in bioimaging [107], energy storage [108], and catalysts [109]. The intriguing properties, such as chemical stability, high luminesce, and high biocompatibility make them novel luminescent materials [110]. Protein is a major component in microalgae, and is composed of many amino acids. Since amino acids have inherent nitrogen, it is promising to use amino acids as nitrogen sources to modify these materials including carbon quantum dots (CQDs) and graphene quantum dots (GQDs). Generally, amino acids contain carboxylic acid and amino groups which can be cross-linked through dehydration as well as modulate the surface environment of CQDs and GQDs [111]. Furthermore, the heteroatom N in amino acids can be doped in to the carbon framework and change the photoluminescent properties with improvement on quantum yield (QY) [112]. The synthesis methods can be divided into the following categories: electrochemical synthesis, hydrothermal/carbonization treatment, microwave irradiation, thermolysis synthesis. In a report by Niu et al. [113], amino acids, as precursors, were used to prepare N-doped CQDs (N-CQDs) in a simple electrochemical system in less than 2 h (Scheme 7 ). Briefly, the synthetic process is in a three-electrode system that employed two Pt sheets and Ag/AgCl as the working electrode, counter electrode and an auxiliary electrode, respectively. According to TEM, the N-CQDs dispersed well in water with a diameter of 2.95 nm. Also, N-CQDs, based on aspartic acid, obtained the highest QY value (46.2 %) and showed photoluminescence properties under UV irradiation. Zeng et al. [114] employed a one-pot hydrothermal method to produce N, S co-doped carbon dots (CDs). A specific amount of l-cystine and l-serine was heated to 200 ℃ for 5 h. Then the solution was dialyzed followed by a freeze-drying process to obtain N,S co-doped carbon dots (CDs). In the synthesis process, l-cystine and l-serine worked as carbon and nitrogen source, and l-cystine also provided sulfur source. Yang et al. [115] treated various amino acids hydrothermally at 180 ℃, followed by centrifugation to obtain the supernatant, and then the solution was dialyzed to obtain N-doped CDs (NCDs) (Fig. 14 ). Specifically, the synthesis process was divided into four steps: dehydration, polymerization, carbonization and passivation. Notably, the authors confirmed that the highest quantum yield of NCDs reached 41.3 %. Sarkar and co-workers [116] used amino acids to functionalize CDs with critic acid as carbon core via a bottom-up method. Briefly, amino acids were mixed with NaOH to form carboxylate salt followed by the addition of critic acid, and then the solution was evaporated at 100 ℃. Consequently, the as-prepared solid was carbonized at 200 ℃ for 2 h. The synthesized CDs exhibited high stability under ultraviolet light with promising employment in bioimaging. Sahiner and co-workers [117] synthesized nitrogen and/or sulfur- doped carbon dots in a simple step via microwave irradiation using amino acids as raw materials. The dissolution of citric acid and amino acids was put in the microwave at 700 w for several minutes, then sonicated in water for 20 s. Finally, the suspension was filtered, dialyzed, precipitated, and dried. Cystine-derived CDs show the highest quantum yield of 89 % according to quinone sulfate standard at 345 nm excitation wavelength. Cheng et al. [118] synthesized CDs via heating critic acid at 160 ℃ for 3 h, subsequently modified with ethylenediamine (EDA) and amino acids through a reflux process. Especially, the as-prepared samples with various amino acids showed fluorescence response to different metal cations with the potential to be high-throughput screening probes. Li and co-workers [119] described another thermolysis process to fabricate nitrogen-doped and amino acid-functionalized GQDs (NA-GQDs). Specifically, NA-GQDs had a quantum yield of 16.2 %. Besides CDs and GQDs, amino acids can also participate in other functionalized carbon materials. In a report by Wang et al. [120], amino acids and graphene oxide prepared N-doped graphene hydrogels in a hydrothermal process. Huang and co-workers [121] functionalized copper graphene materials with amino acids, showing better catalytic activity for N-arylation than unmodified graphene. Another synthetic process prepared N-doped carbon materials with amino acid as a precursor via a thermolysis process [122]. Specifically, the nitrogen content reached 5% with the surface area of 455 m2/g. Liu and co-workers [123] fabricated N-doped carbon materials with nitrogen content from 1% to 6.3 % using amino acid as a nitrogen dopant. Gao et al. [124] synthesized N-doped mesoporous carbon materials via thermal treatment with SBA-15 silica as a template, exhibiting potential in CO2 capture and oxygen reduction reaction. Ilnicka et al. [125] applied amino acid as a carbon precursor and CaCO3 as a hard template to make N-rich carbon foams with nitrogen content from 4.1 to 12.4 wt%. In conclusion, amino acids can modify carbon-based quantum dots, and the introduction of nitrogen profoundly improved their applications in biomedicine, catalyst, and storage. Additionally, different amino acids may have diverse influences on the efficiency of carbon materials. The compositions of the precursors are important in the synthesis procedure, which may largely decide the final QY of the CDs. Among the four synthesis approaches, electrochemical and microwave process are inexpensive, however, the combination of these methods may be developed to promote the fluorescent performance for a higher QYs. 3.2 Conversion into nitrogen-containing chemicals Besides various materials, amino acids can be transformed into different NCCs with a great future in pharmaceutical, building, and dyeing. This report mainly focused on the decarboxylation reactions of amino acids to synthesize versatile compounds, and the categories of NCCs via decarboxylation are classified into the following groups. 3.2.1 Conversion into amines and other products by direct decarboxylation Amines are critical NCCs in the field of agrochemicals, drugs, and detergents, and also, amines are significant in chemical synthesis [126]. In 1986, HASHIMOTO et al. [127] reported that direct decarboxylation of various amino acids with 2-cyclohexen-l-one as the catalyst. Laval and Golding [128] synthesized amines from α-amino acids via oxidative decarboxylation and subsequent reduction. Amino acids were treated with N-bromosuccinimide in phosphate buffer at pH 5 or alcoholic solvent, followed by a reduction reaction in a system consisted of nickel chloride and NaBH4. In addition to amines, Yamano et al. [129] obtained 2-pyrrolidone from glutamic acid, combining a biological process with a chemical method (Fig. 15 ). Amino acids were converted to γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) by fermentation of Escherichia coli, which subsequently transformed to 2-pyrrolidone via intramolecular condensation. To overcome the limits in enzymatic decarboxylation, Schouwer et al. [130] proposed a chemical catalytic way to form 2-pyrrolidone using Pd-based catalysts. 5 wt% Pd/Al2O3 performed best with a yield of 70 % in water at 250 ℃. Later, Suganuma et al. [131] proposed a new system to yield 2-pyrrolidone in a milder condition. Ru/Al2O3 showed the highest catalytic activity and obtained a high yield of 2-pyrrolidone at 160 ℃ under 2 Mpa H2. Jackson et al. [132] developed a new approach to decarboxylate amino acids using R-carvone as a catalyst under superheated condition by microwave or oil bath in n-propanol. Unlike conventional decarboxylation processes, the catalyst in this reaction was green and non-toxic. Enzyme and novel metal catalysts are effective in direct decarboxylation. Due to long reaction time of enzyme and high cost of novel metals, it is difficult to achieve industrialization. Besides, Ketone or aldehyde is useful to realize the conversion but limited to specific amino acids. As a result, develop cheap metal catalyst may make decarboxylation easy to implement. 3.2.2 Conversion into nitriles by oxidative decarboxylation Nitriles, the precursors of some organic synthesis, can be produced in an oxidative decarboxylation reaction of amino acids. Hiegel and co-workers [133] reported that amino acids were converted to nitriles with trichloroisocyanuric acid in water or methanol. In another report by Nôtre et al. [134], glutamic acid was transformed to acrylonitrile via two steps containing oxidative decarboxylation and further decarbonylation-elimination. Without sodium hypochlorite, Dai et al. [135] synthesized adiponitrile from glutamic acid via an electrochemical method and Kolbe coupling. The synthesis of glutamic acid 5-methyl ester (Glu-Me) adopted a method proposed by Baldwin and co‐workers [136]. Glu-Me was converted to 3-cyanopropanoic acid methyl ester (CPA-Me) with two platinum electrodes using the mixture of methanol and water as a solvent. Next, CPA-Me went through a saponification reaction and finally generated adiponitrile in Kolbe coupling. Le Nôtre et al. [137] proposed the synthesis of nitriles from amino acids with vanadium chloroperoxidase enzyme (VCPO) and H2O2. Another study by Claes et al. [138] synthesized nitriles from amino acids via oxidative decarboxylation in a heterogeneous catalytic system. Tungstate supported on [Ni, Al] layered double hydroxide ([Ni, Al]-LDH) was the catalyst for in situ bromide oxidation and completed oxidative decarboxylation of amino acids under mild conditions. Afterward, the group used ruthenium-based catalysts to produce nitriles with molecular oxygen as a sole oxidant for the first time [139]. The advantage of this reaction was no usage of halides or other salts, and a mechanism was proposed (Scheme 8 ): first, amino acids entered the catalytic system via exchanging amino group with ligand on the Ru followed by the β-hydride elimination into an α-iminocarboxylate and a Ru-monohydride species, and then an oxygen was inserted in Ru-H bond. Finally, the obtained species were decarboxylated to release CO2 and the catalysts were regenerated. Oxidative decarboxylation is a key step in nitrile synthesize, and needs oxidants such as hypohalite species. However, these oxidants will influence product purity. Developing a sustainable oxidant is beneficial to the synthesis; for example, molecular oxygen is an excellent oxidant and deserved to be studied. 3.2.3 Decarboxylation coupling Decarboxylation coupling is an approach to synthesize valuable chemicals which are widely used in pharmaceutical industries. Amino acids, easily available in protein, have great potentiality in synthesizing N-heterocycles, including quinazolines [140]. According to the reaction conditions, the coupling process can be divided into the following groups. 3.2.3.1 Metal-catalyzed decarboxylative couplings Transition metal-catalyzed cross-couplings played a vital part in the organic synthesis via CC bond formation. Bi et al. [141] improved intermolecular decarboxylative coupling of α-amino acids with CuBr as a catalyst. Later, to expand the reaction scope, the group developed a novel iron-catalyzed Csp3 – Csp2 decarboxylative coupling with proline derivatives as raw materials [142]. Furthermore, Bi and co-workers [143] designed an intermolecular tandem decarboxylation-coupling induced by aldehyde and ketone with copper as the catalyst. The reaction was more sustainable, generating H2O and CO2 as side products. In another study by Firouzabadi et al. [144], CeO2 was the promoter of aldehyde-induced decarboxylative coupling reaction of l-proline with triethyl phosphite and nitromethane. Quinazolinones were first synthesized using copper as the catalyst based on 2-halobenzamides and α-amino acids in a domino synthesis [145]. The reaction went through Ullmann-type N-arylation, decarboxylation, aerobic oxidation, and intramolecular addition (Fig. 16 ). Liu et al. [146] developed a route to synthesize N-fused heterocycles with α-amino acids as the nitrogen source catalyzed by copper. Luo and De Brabander [147] coupled α-amino acids with N-Boc-2-iodoanilines to synthesize quinoxalinones in mild conditions. Ligand-free copper catalyzed the reactants to form N-arylated amino acids, which subsequently converted to quinoxalinones via an acid-mediated cyclization. Interestingly, even using arylglycine substrates, there was no racemization in the whole process. In a report by Wu et al. [148], α-amino acids went through decarboxylative N-alkylation with primary alcohols catalyzed by a Cp*Ir complex and eventually achieved tertiary amines in good yields. Afanasenko et al. [149] realized decarboxylative N-alkylation of α-amino acids with various alcohols. Although Fe-based catalysts did not perform as well as Cu-based catalysts, Fe-based system was nontoxic and abundant on earth, which could synthesize saturated azaheterocycles more sustainably. As mentioned above, transition metal-catalyzed couplings are the most common way to form CC or CN bonds. However, this approach is expensive, and some even need complex ligands. In addition, some couplings might demand a high-temperature reaction. 3.2.3.2 Metal-free decarboxylative couplings In a study by Wang et al. [150], pyridine derivatives were synthesized via decarboxylative cyclization without metal. Enlighted by the process, the group proposed a novel synthesis of quinazolines based on α-amino acids and 2-aminobenzaldehydes or 2-aminobenzoketones via I2/oxidant-mediated decarboxylative coupling [140]. Then the group used α-amino acids and N-heterocyclic carbaldehydes as starting materials to produce imidazo[1,5-a]N-heterocycles via decarboxylative cyclizations [151]. A reaction mechanism was proposed as follows: imine (Ⅰ) was formed by the condensation of amino acids (1a) and aldehydes (2a), which further went through N-iodination (Ⅱ), decarboxylation by KHCO3 (Ⅲ a), tautomerization (Ⅲ b), cyclization (Ⅳ), and removal of a hydrogen iodide to generate the target product (3a) (Scheme 9 ). Seidel et al. [152] developed a novel azomethine ylide annulation that synthesized polycyclic ring systems from amino acids and aldehydes which were linked to a pronucleophile. Afterward, Kang and Seidel [153] synthesized indolizidine and quinolizidine derivatives using α‑amino acids and γ-nitroaldehydes as starting materials. Tang et al. [154] reported the synthesis of 2,5-dihydro-1H-benzo[c]azepines and 1011-dihydro-5H-benzo[e]pyrrolo[1,2-a]azepines from the annulations of α-amino acids and aromatic aldehydes which contained an ortho-Michael acceptor. Clift’s group [155] demonstrated a new route for amino acid homologation, of which the amino acids were converted to β-amino acids esters catalyzed by quinone. Recently, Zhou and co-workers [156] synthesized N-alkyl-β-alkenyl cyclic amines from amino acids via aldehyde-induced decarboxylation. Unlike other reactions focused on the α- functionalized methods, this process proposed a difunctionalizative reaction of amino acids in the N- and β-C(sp 3)-H with high stereoselectivity. Metal-free decarboxylative couplings largely reduced reaction costs and were benign to the environment under mild conditions. Also, some researchers synthesized various chemicals that are not available in traditional methods, displaying potential applications in organic synthesize. 3.2.3.3 Photoredox catalysis decarboxylative couplings In 2014, Zuo and MacMillan [157] successfully produced benzylic amines via direct decarboxylative arylation of α-amino acids by photoredox catalysis. Li et al. [158] proposed a visible light photocatalytic decarboxylative monofluoroalkentlation of α-amino acids with gem-difluoroalkenes. Recently, the reaction system combined transition metal with photoredox catalysis has raised much attention. Decarboxylative allylation of α-amino acids in a dual system containing palladium and photoredox catalysis was proposed to overcome difficulties in decarboxylative couplings [159]. Luo and Zhang [160] confirmed that carbazolyl dicyanobenzene (CDCB)-based donor-acceptor (DA) fluorophores could function as metal-free catalysts for organic synthesis. The photocatalyst promoted the photoredox/Ni dual decarboxylative cross-coupling of α-amino acids with aryl halides. Without high temperatures, a large number of chemicals can also be produced in mild conditions via photocatalysis. Moreover, the combination of photoredox catalysis with transition metal offers more opportunities to generate NCCs. Visible light-mediated decarboxylative couplings of α-amino acids broaden the ways of organic synthesis with high efficiency and functional group tolerance. 4 Conclusion Marine biomass is potentially reliable feedstocks and resources for the synthesis of versatile chemicals and functional materials, especially NCCs. Taking advantage of inherent nitrogen in biomass can effectively mitigate the threats to the environment and increase atom efficiency. However, there is still a long way to go to make full use of marine biomass. Converting chitin into various chemicals has been investigated a lot; more researches need to be done to synthesize other valuable NCCs and improve the transformation mechanism. On the other hand, since amino acids in microalgae are diverse, utilizing nitrogen in microalgae is still at an early stage. Organic synthesis from amino acids usually focuses on specific amino acid, which may not be favorable for other amino acids. Besides, some organic reagents used in the synthesis are harmful to the environment. In the future, a good understanding of specific reaction conditions is necessary, ensuring high yield and selectivity of target chemicals. Besides, more importance should be attached to the direct synthesis of NCCs from shells to reduce complexity and costs. The existence of -NH2 and −COOH in amino acids provides more possibilities to fabricate valuable chemicals. Without extra nitrogen incorporation, chitin and amino acids can be used to produce various functional materials with great potentiality in catalysis, energy storage, and bioimaging. coredata.dc:description: Chitin and microalgae, naturally occurring nitrogen-rich marine resources, have vast applications in chemical production and material synthesis. Being undervalued and underutilized for a long time, marine biomass biorefinery has attracted considerable attention to realize its economic value in the last few years to meet the sustainable development requirements. This review first analyzes the chemical constituent of chitin and microalgae to understand their basic chemical properties. Next, various transformation pathways to value-added nitrogenous chemicals are summarized, and the biologically fixed nitrogen in marine biomass can be fully utilized with the reduced amount of energy-intensive synthetic NH3. Additionally, the biomass can also be used as precursors to synthesize functional N- doped carbon materials, which are potential candidates in catalysts, energy storage, and biomedical field. This review can provide insights into the fundamental understanding on the intrinsic nature and appropriate transformation options for N-rich marine biomass as renewable replacement of non-sustainable petroleum resources, and also disclose the nitrogen utilization from biomass for wider and more sustainable applications to enrich the chemicals production process.
coredata.dc:title: Sustainable nitrogen-containing chemicals and materials from natural marine resources chitin and microalgae
